segment.source: Configure Windows Firewall with Advanced Security by Using an Answer File
segment.target: Configure Windows Firewall with Advanced Security by Using an Answer File

segment.source: Configure Windows Firewall with Advanced Security by Using an Answer File
segment.target: Configure Windows Firewall with Advanced Security by Using an Answer File

segment.source: Configure Windows Firewall with Advanced Security by Using an Answer File
segment.target: Configure Windows Firewall with Advanced Security by Using an Answer File

segment.source: For unattended installations, you can configure Windows® Firewall with Advanced Security settings in an answer file by using the Networking-MPSSVC-Svc component.
segment.target: For unattended installations, you can configure Windows® Firewall with Advanced Security settings in an answer file by using the Networking-MPSSVC-Svc component.

segment.source: In addition to the answer file (Unattend.xml) settings for Windows Firewall with Advanced Security, you can create a RunSynchronous command that runs Netsh advfirewall commands during the auditUser or oobeSystem configuration pass.
segment.target: In addition to the answer file (Unattend.xml) settings for Windows Firewall with Advanced Security, you can create a RunSynchronous command that runs Netsh advfirewall commands during the auditUser or oobeSystem configuration pass.

segment.source: Adding, Modifying, or Deleting Rules for Windows Firewall with Advanced Security
segment.target: Adding, Modifying, or Deleting Rules for Windows Firewall with Advanced Security

segment.source: Use RunSynchronous commands only to add, modify, or delete rules for Windows Firewall with Advanced Security.
segment.target: Use RunSynchronous commands only to add, modify, or delete rules for Windows Firewall with Advanced Security.

segment.source: To modify rule groups, use the FirewallGroups setting in the Networking-MPSSVC-Svc component.
segment.target: To modify rule groups, use the FirewallGroups setting in the Networking-MPSSVC-Svc component.

segment.source: For more information about Windows components and settings that you can add to an answer file, see the Unattended Windows Setup Reference Guide.
segment.target: For more information about Windows components and settings that you can add to an answer file, see the Unattended Windows Setup Reference Guide.

segment.source: To add a Netsh command to an answer file
segment.target: To add a Netsh command to an answer file

segment.source: On your technician computer, open Windows System Image Manager (Windows SIM).
segment.target: On your technician computer, open Windows System Image Manager (Windows SIM).

segment.source: Click Start, type Windows System Image Manager, and then select Windows System Image Manager.
segment.target: Click Start, type Windows System Image Manager, and then select Windows System Image Manager.

segment.source: Create a new answer file, or update an existing answer file.
segment.target: Create a new answer file, or update an existing answer file.

segment.source: For more information, see Create or Open an Answer File and Best Practices for Authoring Answer Files.
segment.target: For more information, see Create or Open an Answer File and Best Practices for Authoring Answer Files.

segment.source: On the Insert menu, click RunSynchronous.
segment.target: On the Insert menu, click RunSynchronous.

segment.source: Select the configuration pass where you want to install the command.
segment.target: Select the configuration pass where you want to install the command.

segment.source: This can be the auditUser or oobeSystem configuration pass.
segment.target: This can be the auditUser or oobeSystem configuration pass.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: Don't use the RunSynchronousNetsh advfirewall command during the specialize configuration pass.
segment.target: Don't use the RunSynchronousNetsh advfirewall command during the specialize configuration pass.

segment.source: The Create Synchronous Command dialog box appears.
segment.target: The Create Synchronous Command dialog box appears.

segment.source: In the Enter command line box, type the command-line syntax, like Netsh advfirewall firewall.
segment.target: In the Enter command line box, type the command-line syntax, like Netsh advfirewall firewall.

segment.source: For more information, see the Network Shell (Netsh) Technical Reference.
segment.target: For more information, see the Network Shell (Netsh) Technical Reference.

segment.source: In the Order box, select the order of the commands that will run, and then click OK.
segment.target: In the Order box, select the order of the commands that will run, and then click OK.

segment.source: The command is added to the answer file in the selected configuration pass, as follows:
segment.target: The command is added to the answer file in the selected configuration pass, as follows:

segment.source: Commands that are added to the 6 auditUser passes configuration pass appear in the setting Microsoft-Windows-DeploymentRunSynchronous.
segment.target: Commands that are added to the 6 auditUser passes configuration pass appear in the setting Microsoft-Windows-DeploymentRunSynchronous.

segment.source: Commands that are added to the 7 oobeSystem configuration pass appear in the setting Microsoft-Windows-Shell-SetupFirstLogonCommands.
segment.target: Commands that are added to the 7 oobeSystem configuration pass appear in the setting Microsoft-Windows-Shell-SetupFirstLogonCommands.

segment.source: In the SynchronousCommand Properties pane, in the Settings section next to Description, enter a description like Enable Windows Messenger.
segment.target: In the SynchronousCommand Properties pane, in the Settings section next to Description, enter a description like Enable Windows Messenger.

segment.source: The command is added to the answer file under the configuration pass that you selected.
segment.target: The command is added to the answer file under the configuration pass that you selected.

segment.source: This example illustrates how an incoming rule for Windows Messenger is configured:
segment.target: This example illustrates how an incoming rule for Windows Messenger is configured:

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: The Netsh advfirewall command requires administrator permissions to run.
segment.target: The Netsh advfirewall command requires administrator permissions to run.

segment.source: If the RunSynchronous command runs in a configuration pass that runs in user context, that user account must have administrator permissions.
segment.target: If the RunSynchronous command runs in a configuration pass that runs in user context, that user account must have administrator permissions.

segment.source: Using the Netsh Advfirewall Command-Line Tool
segment.target: Using the Netsh Advfirewall Command-Line Tool

segment.source: The following example illustrates how to add a new outgoing firewall rule to block a port by using the Netsh advfirewall command-line tool.
segment.target: The following example illustrates how to add a new outgoing firewall rule to block a port by using the Netsh advfirewall command-line tool.

segment.source: To add a new outgoing firewall rule
segment.target: To add a new outgoing firewall rule

segment.source: At an elevated command prompt, enter syntax that adds a new outgoing firewall rule to block a port.
segment.target: At an elevated command prompt, enter syntax that adds a new outgoing firewall rule to block a port.

segment.source: For example:
segment.target: For example:

segment.source: where the blocked port is TCP port 80.
segment.target: where the blocked port is TCP port 80.

segment.source: You can convert Netsh commands to Windows PowerShell commands.
segment.target: You can convert Netsh commands to Windows PowerShell commands.

segment.source: For more information, see the Netshell to Powershell Conversion Guide.
segment.target: For more information, see the Netshell to Powershell Conversion Guide.
